oerlikon_metco_specification.source: Oerlikon Metco Material Product Data Sheet - MetcoAdd 17-4PH series
oerlikon_metco_specification.status: PRIMARY STANDARD - This is our powder specification
oerlikon_metco_specification.note: Nominal values from Oerlikon Metco. This is the composition of the powder we are actually using (MetcoAdd 17-4PH-A, Order No. 1093744).

din_en_10088_1_specification.status: FOR REFERENCE - European standard for wrought material
din_en_10088_1_specification.note: DIN standard provides composition ranges. Note: Our Oerlikon powder nominal values fall within these ranges.

comparison_notes.cr_comparison: Oerlikon nominal: 17.0 wt% | DIN range: 15.0-17.0 wt% | Status: Within range ✓
comparison_notes.ni_comparison: Oerlikon nominal: 4.5 wt% | DIN range: 3.0-5.0 wt% | Status: Within range ✓
comparison_notes.cu_comparison: Oerlikon nominal: 4.0 wt% | DIN range: 3.0-5.0 wt% | Status: Within range ✓
comparison_notes.nb_ta_comparison: Oerlikon nominal: 0.3 wt% (Nb+Ta) | DIN range: 5×C-0.45 wt% (Nb only) | Status: Within expected range ✓
comparison_notes.c_comparison: Oerlikon: <0.07 wt% | DIN: max 0.07 wt% | Status: Consistent ✓
comparison_notes.overall: Oerlikon MetcoAdd 17-4PH-A composition is consistent with DIN EN 10088-1 specification for 1.4542

powder_specification.oerlikon_specification_statement: MetcoAdd™ 17-4PH is a family of martensitic, precipitation-hardening stainless steel powders with chemistry similar to AMS 5643. MetcoAdd 17-4PH-A specifically conforms to: AMS 5643, UNS S17400
powder_specification.specification_note: This Oerlikon specification determines our primary standard hierarchy: AMS/ASTM/UNS standards are primary (American system), EN/DIN are secondary

manufacturer_nominal_values.note: Nominal values from Oerlikon Metco Material Product Data Sheet

measurement_1.measurement_method: Laser diffraction using Bettersizer S3 Plus (3P Instruments)
measurement_1.source: Platz, J. et al. (2024) 'Investigation on different laser-powder alignments and their influence on part properties in high-speed Directed Energy Deposition', Procedia CIRP, LANE 2024

measurement_2.measurement_method: Laser diffraction using Bettersizer S3 Plus (3P Instruments)
measurement_2.source: Platz, J. et al. (2024) 'Fertigung funktional gradierter Materialien auf porösen Metallen durch Laserauftragschweißen', ZWF 119(7-8), pp. 515-519

actual_batch_measurements.note: Measured values from actual powder batches used in experiments. Measurement_1 provides complete data including D50.

batch_variation.explanation: Batch-to-batch variation is normal in powder manufacturing. Actual measurements should be performed for each new batch. The two measurements show similar trends, confirming systematic deviation from nominal values.

standard_designations.note: Material similar to AMS 5643 specification. ISO/JIS/GB designations from DIN EN 10088-1:2024-04, Annex A, Table A.1

measurement_conditions.state: Powder form properties at room temperature

source_hierarchy.principle: Oerlikon specifies MetcoAdd 17-4PH-A as 'chemistry similar to AMS 5643, UNS S17400', which determines that AMS/ASTM/UNS standards are PRIMARY (American system) and EN/DIN are SECONDARY for this material.

sources: 1a. Your direct measurements (Platz et al. 2024) - what you actually measured on your powder batches
1b. Oerlikon Metco datasheets for MetcoAdd 17-4PH-A - the powder you actually use (batch-specific)

tier_2_primary_standards.justification: Oerlikon specification 'similar to AMS 5643, UNS S17400' drives preference for American standards
sources: 2b. ASTM standards (American system - A564, A693, etc.)

tier_3_authoritative_research.justification: Peer-reviewed, citable research with high-quality experimental data
sources: 3a. ASM Handbooks (American system, aligns with AMS/ASTM)
3b. Mills (2002) 'Recommended Values' - when applicable by analogy
3c. NIST measurements - when available for similar alloys

tier_4_industry_consensus.justification: Multiple independent industry sources provide validation
sources: 4a. Multiple industry datasheets agreeing (Ulbrich, Sandmeyer, SLM Solutions, MFG Shop)

tier_5_secondary_standards.justification: Secondary for 17-4PH but still authoritative for reference

application_rules.particle_size: Tier 1a - YOUR measurements (Platz papers) - actual batch characterization
application_rules.melting_temperatures: Tier 1b - OERLIKON specs - batch-specific for your exact powder (Solidus: 1456°C, Liquidus: 1491°C)
application_rules.composition: Tier 1b - OERLIKON nominal values - your actual powder specification
application_rules.when_sources_conflict: Follow tier hierarchy; document alternatives in metadata with reasoning. For 17-4PH, American standards (AMS/ASTM/ASM) take precedence over European standards (DIN/EN).
application_rules.analogies: When no direct 17-4PH data exists, prefer analogies from similar precipitation-hardening steels over austenitic steels

rationale.why_ams_primary: Oerlikon explicitly specifies 'chemistry similar to AMS 5643' which is the American aerospace material specification. This makes AMS/ASTM/ASM the primary reference system for this specific powder.
rationale.why_oerlikon_for_melting: Melting temperatures are highly composition-dependent. Oerlikon's batch-specific values (Solidus: 1456°C ± 10°C, Liquidus: 1491°C ± 10°C) reflect the actual powder composition. ASM Handbook Vol 1 reports generic 17-4PH at 1400-1440°C (56°C lower), likely due to composition variations within the broad 17-4PH specification range (Cr: 15-17.5%, Ni: 3-5%, Cu: 3-5%).
rationale.why_asm_over_din: ASM Handbooks align with the American materials system (AMS/ASTM) which is primary for this material. ASM Vol 1 reports thermal conductivity 18.3 W/(m·K) and specific heat 460 J/(kg·K), which should be weighted more heavily than DIN EN 10088-1 values when they conflict.
rationale.industry_consensus_note: Multiple industry sources (Ulbrich, Sandmeyer, SLM Solutions, MFG Shop) agree on: density 7800 kg/m³, thermal conductivity 16.0 W/(m·K), specific heat 460 J/(kg·K). This consensus aligns with ASM specific heat but differs from ASM thermal conductivity (18.3 vs 16.0 W/(m·K)).
rationale.data_scarcity: 17-4PH has limited high-temperature thermophysical data compared to 316L. Many properties (surface tension, viscosity, latent heat) are estimated by analogy and require experimental verification.

solidus_temp.source: Oerlikon Metco Material Product Data Sheet for MetcoAdd 17-4PH-A: Solidus = 1456°C ± 10°C (1729K ± 10K)

liquidus_temp.source: Oerlikon Metco Material Product Data Sheet for MetcoAdd 17-4PH-A: Liquidus = 1491°C ± 10°C (1764K ± 10K)

melting_temp.source: Calculated as average of solidus and liquidus from Oerlikon Metco datasheet: (1729 + 1764) / 2 = 1746.5K

particle_radius.source: MEASURED VALUE USED: D50 = 32.59 µm from Platz et al. (2024) LANE paper → radius = 16.3 µm = 1.63e-5 m. Measurement using Bettersizer S3 Plus on actual powder batch used in experiments. Manufacturer nominal: D50=30 µm (1.5e-5 m).
particle_radius.important_note: This value is specific to the powder batch used in the referenced experiments. Different batches may have different particle size distributions (±5-15% variation observed across two independent measurements). Always measure actual batch when conducting new experiments.

density.source: Multiple sources confirm this value: (1) SLM Solutions datasheet: 7.8 g/cm³ = 7800 kg/m³; (2) Ulbrich Stainless Steels & Special Metals: 0.28 lbs/in³ = 7750 kg/m³; (3) Sandmeyer Steel Company: 0.280 lbs/in³ = 7750 kg/m³. (4) DIN EN 10088-1:2024-04 Table E.4: 7.8 kg/dm³ = 7800 kg/m³. Average: ~7775 kg/m³, rounded to 7800 kg/m³.
density.status: VERIFIED - consensus from multiple industry datasheets AND DIN standard
sources_list: Ulbrich Stainless Steels 17-4 PH Technical Data

specific_heat.source: DIN EN 10088-1:2024-04, Table E.4 (normative standard for 1.4542 at 20°C) specifies 500 J/(kg·K). MFG Shop reference also reports ~500 J/(kg·K). Industry datasheets report lower values: Ulbrich Stainless Steels and Sandmeyer Steel Company both specify 0.11 BTU/(lb·°F) = 460 J/(kg·K) for heat-treated 17-4PH.
sources_list: Ulbrich Stainless Steels 17-4 PH Technical Data
specific_heat.note: DIN standard value (500 J/(kg·K)) is used as primary value following normative specification, also supported by MFG Shop reference. Value is ~4% lower than 316L (520 J/(kg·K)), consistent with martensitic vs austenitic microstructure differences.

industry_deviation.industry_sources: Ulbrich Stainless Steels, Sandmeyer Steel Company
industry_deviation.analysis: Ulbrich and Sandmeyer datasheets consistently report 460 J/(kg·K) for precipitation-hardened 17-4PH, while DIN EN 10088-1 and MFG Shop reference specify 500 J/(kg·K). Possible explanations: (1) Different heat treatment state (solution annealed vs precipitation hardened), (2) Different measurement methods, (3) Variation in alloy composition within specification range.
industry_deviation.recommendation: For critical thermal simulations, consider sensitivity analysis using both 500 J/(kg·K) (DIN/MFG Shop) and 460 J/(kg·K) (Ulbrich/Sandmeyer) to bound predictions. Thermal diffusivity calculated with 500 J/(kg·K) gives α = 4.10×10⁻⁶ m²/s vs 4.46×10⁻⁶ m²/s with 460 J/(kg·K) (8% difference).

thermal_conductivity.source: Multiple sources confirm this value at 20°C: (1) SLM Solutions datasheet: 16 W/(m·K); (2) Ulbrich/Sandmeyer datasheets: ~16-18 W/(m·K); (3) DIN EN 10088-1:2024-04 Table E.4: 16 W/(m·K). Value of 16 W/(m·K) is consensus across ALL sources.
thermal_conductivity.status: VERIFIED - consensus from industry datasheets AND DIN standard
sources_list: Ulbrich Stainless Steels 17-4 PH Technical Data
thermal_conductivity.note: Perfect agreement between all sources (industry + DIN standard)

thermal_diffusivity.source: CALCULATED from α = k/(ρ·cp) where k = 16.0 W/(m·K) (SLM Solutions, industry datasheets, DIN standard), ρ = 7800 kg/m³ (verified from multiple sources + DIN), cp = 500 J/(kg·K) (DIN EN 10088-1:2024-04). Calculation: α = 16.0 / (7800 × 500) = 4.1026×10⁻⁶ m²/s

components.thermal_conductivity: 16.0 W/(m·K) from SLM Solutions, industry datasheets, and DIN EN 10088-1
components.density: 7800 kg/m³ from multiple industry sources and DIN EN 10088-1
components.specific_heat: 500 J/(kg·K) from DIN EN 10088-1:2024-04, Table E.4 (normative standard)

thermal_diffusivity.note: Previous value was 4.46×10⁻⁶ m²/s (calculated with industry cp = 460 J/(kg·K)). Updated to use DIN standard cp = 500 J/(kg·K), resulting in α = 4.10×10⁻⁶ m²/s. 17-4PH thermal diffusivity (4.10×10⁻⁶ m²/s) is ~25% higher than 316L (3.28×10⁻⁶ m²/s) due to higher thermal conductivity and lower specific heat.
thermal_diffusivity.sensitivity_note: If using industry cp value (460 J/(kg·K) instead of 500), thermal diffusivity would be 4.46×10⁻⁶ m²/s (8% higher). Industry datasheets (Ulbrich, Sandmeyer) consistently report 460 J/(kg·K) for precipitation-hardened 17-4PH. Consider sensitivity analysis for critical thermal simulations.

surface_tension.source: ESTIMATED BY ANALOGY - No direct measurements found for 17-4PH molten surface tension. Value estimated by analogy to austenitic stainless steels (316L: ~1.3-1.6 N/m from Mills 2002). Martensitic stainless steels may have slightly different surface tension due to compositional differences (Cu: 3-5%, Ni: 3-5% vs 316L with Ni: 12%).
surface_tension.note: Surface tension is strongly affected by sulfur content and temperature. Without experimental data for 17-4PH, this value has high uncertainty.

viscosity.source: ESTIMATED BY ANALOGY - No direct measurements found for 17-4PH molten viscosity. Value estimated by analogy to molten stainless steels (typical range: 4-7 mPa·s). Mills (2002) notes that viscosity for 316L was 'estimated by analogy with pure iron and Ni'.
viscosity.note: Viscosity of molten metals is difficult to measure and often estimated. This value should be refined through experimental measurement or comparison with similar alloys.

epsilon.source: ESTIMATED - Mills (2002) shows for 316L that emissivity is highly surface-dependent: 0.1-0.2 for polished surfaces, ~0.7 for oxidized surfaces. Value of 0.30 estimated for 17-4PH powder particles (rough surface, not heavily oxidized). Slightly lower than 316L (0.35) due to potentially different oxide characteristics of martensitic vs austenitic steel.
epsilon.note: Emissivity depends strongly on surface condition. For simulation, sensitivity analysis recommended as emissivity can vary 0.1-0.7.

laser_absorptivity.source: NO DIRECT MEASUREMENTS FOUND for 17-4PH in any laser AM process at 1000-1100 nm. Estimated by analogy to 316L (DED range: 0.25-0.75, typical ~0.36-0.50). Slightly lower than 316L (0.50 vs 0.50) acknowledging that martensitic microstructure and composition differences (Cu content, lower Ni) may affect absorptivity.
limitations: NO EXPERIMENTAL DATA EXISTS for 17-4PH absorptivity in laser AM
Value estimated purely by analogy to 316L - substantial uncertainty
17-4PH has different microstructure (martensitic) and composition (3-5% Cu) than 316L
Value is process-dependent (power, speed, spot size)
Simulation does not model: powder-laser interaction, multiple reflections, dynamic surface changes
This represents effective energy coupling, not pure material absorptivity
laser_absorptivity.note: Parameter MUST be refined through comparison of simulated vs measured melt pool geometry for any quantitative predictions. Current value is order-of-magnitude estimate only.

latent_heat_of_fusion.source: ESTIMATED - currently using placeholder value. Mills (2002) provides 260,000 J/kg for 316L (austenitic). No direct measurements found for 17-4PH (martensitic precipitation-hardening steel) in literature. Value should be similar to other stainless steels (250,000-290,000 J/kg range) but composition-dependent.
latent_heat_of_fusion.note: Latent heat depends on composition. 17-4PH has significant Cu content (3-5%) and different phase structure than 316L. Experimental measurement recommended for accurate simulation.

metadata.notes: Martensitic precipitation-hardening stainless steel powder for DED-LB additive manufacturing. Properties at reference temperature (25°C) unless otherwise specified. High-temperature dependent properties (surface tension, viscosity) are for molten state.

descriptions.density: Mass per unit volume of the solid material
descriptions.specific_heat: Amount of heat required to raise the temperature of 1 kg of material by 1 K
descriptions.thermal_diffusivity: Rate at which heat diffuses through the material; calculated as k/(ρ·cp)
descriptions.thermal_conductivity: Rate of heat conduction through the material
descriptions.surface_tension: Force per unit length at the liquid-gas interface; governs melt pool shape and wetting behavior
descriptions.viscosity: Dynamic viscosity of molten material; resistance to flow in liquid state
descriptions.epsilon: Emissivity; fraction of thermal radiation emitted compared to a perfect black body
descriptions.laser_absorptivity: Fraction of incident laser energy absorbed by the material surface
descriptions.melting_temp: Equilibrium melting temperature; average of solidus and liquidus for single-phase materials
descriptions.solidus_temp: Temperature below which material is completely solid
descriptions.liquidus_temp: Temperature above which material is completely liquid
descriptions.latent_heat_of_fusion: Energy required to transform 1 kg of material from solid to liquid at melting temperature
descriptions.particle_radius: Average radius of spherical powder particles used in DED-LB process

fully_verified: specific_heat (DIN EN 10088-1 standard, with noted industry deviation)
thermal_diffusivity (calculated from verified k, ρ, cp)
chemical_composition (Oerlikon datasheet + DIN EN 10088-1 for reference)
priority_for_experimental_verification: 1. laser_absorptivity - CRITICAL for DED simulation accuracy - MUST calibrate via melt pool comparison
3. viscosity - affects melt pool fluid dynamics
4. surface_tension - affects wetting and melt pool shape
